newsitem.title: POLAND: Zloty flat vs basket despite mark fall, depos down.
newsitem.headline: Zloty flat vs basket despite mark fall, depos down.

text.p: The Polish zloty finished today's light session nearly flat from Wednesday with wide spreads in reaction to volatile dollar/mark swings in Europan trade.
The zloty gained more than half a pfennig to the mark and lost nearly a cent versus the dollar after the German unit tubled following the Bundesbank's deep repo rate cut.
"The market did not have its own trend, it just adjusted to dollar/mark swings after Buba slashed the German repo rate," said Marcin Stefaniuk from BDK SA.
The zloty closed at 1.83/1.67 percent from the trading band centre, virtually flat from Wednesday's 1.81/1.78 percent.
The zloty closed at 2.7420/60 per dollar, down from 2.7335/65 at 0700 GMT and Wednesday's close at 2.7330/40.
It was at 1.8330/85 to the mark, up from against opening's 1.8425/40 and Wednesday's 1.8425/30.

Interbank deposits rates fell on increased liquidity as monthly tax payments ended and the central bank again refrained from draining the market through short-term reserve-repos and opted for longer-term outright fixed bond sales instead.
"Outright sales do not clear all excess cash from the market and with no short-term drainages available, rates are easing," said Pawel Kowalski from Creditanstalt SA.
Overnight rates were quoted at 15.0/17.0 percent, down from 17.4/18.1 at 0645 GMT, and tomorrow/next rates were at 12.0/16.8 percent, down from 17.70/18.35 percent.
At today's outright fixed bond sale the National Bank of Poland sold 83 million zloty of the bonds after banks bid for 151 million zlotys of the paper.
The minimum price of the 17-percent two-year bonds inched up 0.05 point to 99.19 from Wednesday's outright and the average price rose 0.02 point to 99.22.
The minimum price for the 14-percent five-year paper rose 0.05 point to 90.04 and the average price fell 0.05 to 90.04.
Investors bid for 757 million zlotys of 16-percent two-year bonds and for 295 million zlotys of 12-percent five-year bonds at the Treasury's joint 800 million zloty tender.
